1    | /*****
2    |  ** ** Module Header ******************************************************* **
3    |  ** 									     **
4    |  **   Modules Revision 3.0						     **
5    |  **   Providing a flexible user environment				     **
6    |  ** 									     **
7    |  **   File:		init.c						     **
8    |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
9    |  ** 									     **
10   |  **   Authors:	John Furlan, jlf@behere.com				     **
11   |  **		Jens Hamisch, jens@Strawberry.COM			     **
12   |  ** 									     **
13   |  **   Description:	The initialization routines for Tcl Modules.	     **
14   |  **			Primarily the setup of the different Tcl module	     **
15   |  **			commands and the global hash tables are initialized  **
16   |  **			here. The initial storage of the begining	     **
17   |  **			environment is here as well.			     **
18   |  ** 									     **
19   |  **   Exports:		Initialize_Tcl					     **
20   |  **			Module_Tcl_ExitCmd				     **
21   |  **			InitializeModuleCommands			     **
22   |  **			Setup_Environment				     **
23   |  **			TieStdout					     **
24   |  **			UnTieStdout					     **
25   |  **			SetStartupFiles					     **
26   |  **									     **
27   |  **   Notes:								     **
28   |  ** 									     **
29   |  ** ************************************************************************ **
30   |  ****/
31   | 
32   | /** ** Copyright *********************************************************** **
33   |  ** 									     **
34   |  ** Copyright 1991-1994 by John L. Furlan.                      	     **
35   |  ** see LICENSE.GPL, which must be provided, for details		     **
36   |  ** 									     ** 
37   |  ** ************************************************************************ **/
38   | 
39   | static char Id[] = "@(#)$Id: init.c.src.html,v 1.6.30.1 2010/11/11 18:23:20 rkowen Exp $";
40   | static void *UseId[] = { &UseId, Id };
41   |

56   | /** not applicable **/
57   |

59   | /** 				     CONSTANTS				     **/

61   |

66   | /** ************************************************************************ **/

71   | /** 				    LOCAL DATA				     **/
72   | /** ************************************************************************ **/
73   | 
74   | static	char	module_name[] = "init.c";	/** File name of this module **/
75   | 
76   | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_CALLBACK
77   | static	char	_proc_Module_Tcl_ExitCmd[] = "Module_Tcl_ExitCmd";
78   | #endif
79   | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
80   | static	char	_proc_InitializeModuleCommands[] = "InitializeModuleCommands";
81   | static	char	_proc_Initialize_Tcl[] = "Initialize_Tcl";
82   | static	char	_proc_Setup_Environment[] = "Setup_Environment";
83   | #endif
84   | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
85   | static	char	_proc_TieStdout[] = "TieStdout";
86   | static	char	_proc_UnTieStdout[] = "UnTieStdout";
87   | #endif
88   | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL
89   | static	char	_proc_SetStartupFiles[] = "SetStartupFiles";
90   | #endif
91   | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_3
92   | static	char	_proc_set_shell_properties[] = "set_shell_properties";
93   | #endif
94   | 
95   | /** These are the recognized startup files that the given shells
96   |  ** use.  If your site uses a different set, make the modifications here.
97   |  ** Give the names and the order they should be searched. The lists
98   |  ** must be null terminated.
99   |  **/
100  | 
101  | /** CSH **/
102  | static char *cshStartUps[] = {
103  |     ".modules", ".cshrc" DOT_EXT, ".csh_variables", ".login" DOT_EXT, NULL
104  | };
105  | /** TCSH **/
106  | 
107  | static char *tcshStartUps[] = {
108  |     ".modules", ".tcshrc", ".cshrc" DOT_EXT, ".csh_variables",
109  |     ".login" DOT_EXT, NULL
110  | };
111  | 
112  | /** SH and KSH **/
113  | /** KSH uses whatever is pointed to by $ENV, which is usually named .kshenv
114  |  ** (TODO) have it read $ENV and use the value
115  |  **/
116  | 
117  | static char *shStartUps[] = {
118  |     ".modules", ".profile" DOT_EXT, ".kshenv" DOT_EXT, NULL
119  | };
120  | 
121  | /** BASH **/
122  | /** BASH uses whatever is pointed to by $ENV, for non-interactive shells
123  |  ** and for POSIX compliance
124  |  ** (TODO) have it read $ENV and use the value
125  |  **/
126  | 
127  | static char *bashStartUps[] = {
128  |     ".modules", ".bash_profile", ".bash_login",
129  |     ".profile" DOT_EXT, ".bashrc" DOT_EXT, NULL
130  | };
131  | 
132  | /** ZSH **/
133  | 
134  | static char *zshStartUps[] = {
135  |     ".modules", ".zshrc" DOT_EXT, ".zshenv" DOT_EXT, ".zlogin" DOT_EXT, NULL
136  | };
137  | 
138  | /** All the remaining "shells"  are not supposed to use startup files **/
139  | 
140  | static char *genericStartUps[] = {
141  |     NULL
142  | };
143  | 
144  | /** The shell properties matrix - global pointers are set to elements of
145  |  ** this array
146  |  **/
147  | static char *shellprops [][4] = {
148  | /*	shell		derelict	init		cmd sep		*/
149  | 	{"csh",		"csh",		"csh",		";"},
150  | 	{"tcsh",	"csh",		"csh",		";"},
151  | 	{"sh",		"sh",		"sh",		";"},
152  | 	{"ksh",		"sh",		"ksh",		";"},
153  | 	{"bash",	"sh",		"bash",		";"},
154  | 	{"zsh",		"sh",		"zsh",		";"},
155  | 	{"perl",	"perl",		"perl",		";"},
156  | 	{"python",	"python",	"python",	"\n"},
157  | 	{"scm",		"scm",		NULL,		"\n"},
158  | 	{"scheme",	"scm",		NULL,		"\n"},
159  | 	{"guile",	"scm",		NULL,		"\n"},
160  | 	{"mel",		"mel",		NULL,		";"},
161  | 	{"cmake",	"cmake",	"cmake",	"\n"},
162  | 	{NULL,		NULL,		NULL,		NULL},
163  | };
164  | 
165  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
166  | /**				    PROTOTYPES				     **/
167  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
168  | 
169  | static char	*set_shell_properties(	const char	*name);
170  | 
171  | 
172  | /*++++
173  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
174  |  ** 									     **
175  |  **   Function:		Module_Tcl_ExitCmd				     **
176  |  ** 									     **
177  |  **   Description:	Error (???) exit routine			     **
178  |  ** 									     **
179  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
180  |  ** 									     **
181  |  **   Parameters:	ClientData	client_data			     **
182  |  **			Tcl_Interp*	interp		The attached Tcl     **
183  |  **							interpreter	     **
184  |  **			int		argc		Number of arguments  **
185  |  **			char		*argv[]		Array of arguments   **
186  |  **							to the module command**
187  |  ** 									     **
188  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_ERROR		Exit on error	     **
189  |  ** 									     **
190  |  **   Attached Globals:							     **
191  |  ** 									     **
192  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
193  |  ++++*/
194  | 
195  | int Module_Tcl_ExitCmd(	ClientData	  client_data,
196  | 		   	Tcl_Interp	 *interp,
197  | 		   	int 		  argc,
198  | 		   	CONST84 char 	 *argv[])
199  | {
200  |     char *buffer;			/** Buffer for sprintf		     **/
201  |     int  value;				/** Return value from exit command   **/
202  | 
203  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_CALLBACK
204  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_Module_Tcl_ExitCmd, NULL);
205  | #endif
206  | 
207  |     /**
208  |      **  Check the number of arguments. The exit command may take no or one
209  |      **  parameter. So the following is legal:
210  |      **     exit;
211  |      **     exit value;
212  |      **/
213  |     if((argc != 1) && (argc != 2))
214  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_USAGE, LOC, argv[0], "?returnCode?", NULL))
215  | 	    goto unwind0;
216  | 
217  |     /**
218  |      **  If the exit command comes with an paramter, set up the TCL result.
219  |      **  Otherwise the result is 0.
220  |      **/
221  |     if( argc == 1) {
222  | 	value = 0;
223  |     } else if( Tcl_GetInt( interp, argv[1], &value) != TCL_OK) {
224  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_PARAM, LOC, argv[1], NULL))
225  | 	    goto unwind0;
226  |     }
227  | 
228  |     /**
229  |      **  Allocate memory
230  |      **/
231  |     if((char *) NULL == (buffer = stringer(NULL,25,NULL)))
232  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_STRING, LOC, NULL))
233  | 	    goto unwind0;
234  | 
235  |     sprintf( buffer, "EXIT %d", value);
236  |     Tcl_SetResult( interp, buffer, NULL);
237  | 
238  |     /**
239  |      **  Exit from this module command.
240  |      **  ??? Why hardcoded on error ???
241  |      **/
242  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_CALLBACK
243  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_END, LOC, _proc_Module_Tcl_ExitCmd, NULL);
244  | #endif
245  | 
246  | unwind0:
247  |     return( TCL_ERROR);
248  | 
249  | } /** End of 'Module_Tcl_ExitCmd' **/
250  | 
251  | /*++++
252  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
253  |  ** 									     **
254  |  **   Function:		Initialize_Tcl					     **
255  |  ** 									     **
256  |  **   Description:	This procedure is called from 'main' in order to ini-**
257  |  **			tialize the whole thing. The arguments specified on  **
258  |  **			the invoking command line are passed to here.	     **
259  |  ** 									     **
260  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
261  |  ** 									     **
262  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp	**interp	Buffer to store the  **
263  |  **							Tcl interpr. handle  **
264  |  **			int		  argc		Number od args and   **
265  |  **			char		 *argv[]	arg. array from the  **
266  |  **							shell command line   **
267  |  **			char		 *environ[]	Process environment  **
268  |  ** 									     **
269  |  **   Result:		int						     **
270  |  ** 									     **
271  |  **   Attached Globals:	*Ptr		will be initialized		     **
272  |  **			*HashTable	will be allocated and initialized    **
273  |  ** 									     **
274  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
275  |  ++++*/
276  | 
277  | int Initialize_Tcl(	Tcl_Interp	**interp,
278  | 	       		int         	  argc,
279  | 	       		char		 *argv[],
280  |                		char		 *environ[])
281  | {
282  |     int 	Result = TCL_ERROR;
283  |     char *	tmp;
284  | 
285  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
286  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_Initialize_Tcl, NULL);
287  | #endif
288  | 
289  |     /**
290  |      **  Check the command syntax. Since this is already done
291  |      **  Less than 3 parameters isn't valid. Invocation should be
292  |      **   'modulecmd <shell> <command>'
293  |      **/
294  |     if(argc < 2) 
295  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_USAGE, LOC, argv[0], " shellname", NULL))
296  | 	    goto unwind0;
297  | 
298  |     /**
299  |      **  Check the first parameter to modulcmd for a known shell type
300  |      **  and set the shell properties
301  |      **/
302  |     if( !set_shell_properties( argv[1]))
303  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_SHELL, LOC, argv[1], NULL))
304  | 	    goto unwind0;
305  | 
306  |     /**
307  |      **  Create a Tcl interpreter in order to proceed the command. Initialize
308  |      **  this interpreter and set up pointers to all Tcl Module commands
309  |      **  (InitializeModuleCommands)
310  |      **/
311  |  
312  | #ifdef __CYGWIN__
313  |     /* ABr, 12/10/01: from Cygwin stuff */
314  |     Tcl_FindExecutable( argv[0] ) ;
315  | #endif
316  | 
317  |     *interp = Tcl_CreateInterp();
318  |     if( TCL_OK != (Result = InitializeModuleCommands( *interp)))
319  | 	goto unwind0;
320  | 
321  |     /**
322  |      **  Now set up the hash-tables for shell environment modifications.
323  |      **  For a description of these tables have a look at main.c, where
324  |      **  they're defined.  The tables have to be allocated and thereafter
325  |      **  initialized. Exit from the whole program in case allocation fails.
326  |      **/
327  |     if( ( ! ( setenvHashTable = 
328  | 	    (Tcl_HashTable*) module_malloc( sizeof(Tcl_HashTable))) ) ||
329  |         ( ! ( unsetenvHashTable = 
330  | 	    (Tcl_HashTable*) module_malloc( sizeof(Tcl_HashTable))) ) ||
331  |         ( ! ( aliasSetHashTable = 
332  | 	    (Tcl_HashTable*) module_malloc( sizeof(Tcl_HashTable))) ) ||
333  |         ( ! ( aliasUnsetHashTable = 
334  | 	    (Tcl_HashTable*) module_malloc( sizeof(Tcl_HashTable))) ) ||
335  |         ( ! ( markVariableHashTable = 
336  | 	    (Tcl_HashTable*) module_malloc( sizeof(Tcl_HashTable))) ) ||
337  |         ( ! ( markAliasHashTable = 
338  | 	    (Tcl_HashTable*) module_malloc( sizeof(Tcl_HashTable))) ) ) {
339  | 
340  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_ALLOC, LOC, NULL))
341  | 	    goto unwind0;
342  |     }
343  | 
344  |     Tcl_InitHashTable( setenvHashTable, TCL_STRING_KEYS);
345  |     Tcl_InitHashTable( unsetenvHashTable, TCL_STRING_KEYS);
346  |     Tcl_InitHashTable( aliasSetHashTable, TCL_STRING_KEYS);
347  |     Tcl_InitHashTable( aliasUnsetHashTable, TCL_STRING_KEYS);
348  |     Tcl_InitHashTable( markVariableHashTable, TCL_STRING_KEYS);
349  |     Tcl_InitHashTable( markAliasHashTable, TCL_STRING_KEYS);
350  | 
351  | #ifdef BEGINENV
352  | #  if BEGINENV == 99
353  |     /**
354  |      **  Check for the existence of the environment variable
355  |      **  "MODULESBEGINENV".  This signals that for this
356  |      **  configuration that the user wants to record the initial
357  |      **  environment as seen for the first time by the module
358  |      **  command into the filename given in the MODULESBEGINENV
359  |      **  environment variable (which can have one level of
360  |      **  variable expansion).  Whether it's the first time or not
361  |      **  is moderated by the existence of environment variable
362  |      **  _MODULESBEGINENV_ or not.
363  |      **
364  |      **  The update command will use this information to reinitialize the
365  |      **  environment and then reload every modulefile that has been loaded
366  |      **  since as stored in the LOADEDMODULES environment variable in order.
367  |      **/
368  |     if( (tmp = xgetenv( "MODULESBEGINENV")) ) {
369  | 	/* MODULESBEGINENV is set ... use it */
370  | 
371  | 	if( !getenv( "_MODULESBEGINENV_") ) {
372  | 		FILE*  file;
373  | 		if( (file = fopen(tmp, "w+")) ) {
374  | 			int i=0;
375  | 			while( environ[i]) {
376  | 				fprintf( file, "%s\n", environ[i++]);
377  | 			}
378  | 			moduleSetenv( *interp, "_MODULESBEGINENV_", tmp, 1);
379  | 			fclose( file);
380  | 		} else
381  | 			if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_OPEN, LOC,
382  | 			    TCL_RESULT(*interp), "append", NULL))
383  | 			    goto unwind0;
384  | 
385  | 		null_free((void *) &tmp);
386  | 	}
387  |     }
388  | #  else
389  |     /**
390  |      **  Check for the existence of the
391  |      **  environment variable "_MODULESBEGINENV_".  If it is set, then
392  |      **  do nothing, otherwise, Store every environment variable into
393  |      **  ~/.modulesbeginenv.  This will be used to store the environment
394  |      **  variables exactly as it was when Modules saw it for the very first
395  |      **  time.
396  |      **
397  |      **  The update command will use this information to reinitialize the
398  |      **  environment and then reload every modulefile that has been loaded
399  |      **  since as stored in the LOADEDMODULES environment variable in order.
400  |      **/
401  |     if( !getenv( "_MODULESBEGINENV_") ) {
402  | 	/* use .modulesbeginenv */
403  | 
404  |         FILE*  file;
405  | 	
406  |         char savefile[] = "/.modulesbeginenv";
407  | 	char *buffer;
408  | 
409  | 	tmp = getenv("HOME");
410  | 	if((char *) NULL == (tmp = getenv("HOME")))
411  | 	    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_HOME, LOC, NULL))
412  | 		goto unwind0;
413  | 
414  | 	if((char *) NULL == (buffer = stringer(NULL,0,tmp,savefile,NULL)))
415  | 	    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_STRING, LOC, NULL))
416  | 		goto unwind0;
417  | 
418  |             if( file = fopen(buffer, "w+")) {
419  |                 int i=0;
420  |                 while( environ[i]) {
421  |                     fprintf( file, "%s\n", environ[i++]);
422  |                 }
423  |                 moduleSetenv( *interp, "_MODULESBEGINENV_", buffer, 1);
424  |                 fclose( file);
425  |             } else
426  | 		if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_OPEN, LOC,
427  | 		    TCL_RESULT(*interp), "append", NULL))
428  | 		    goto unwind0;
429  | 
430  | 	    null_free((void *) &buffer);
431  |     }
432  | #  endif
433  | #endif
434  | 
435  |     /**
436  |      **  Exit to the main program
437  |      **/
438  |     return( TCL_OK);			/** -------- EXIT (SUCCESS) -------> **/
439  | 
440  | unwind0:
441  |     return( Result);			/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
442  | 
443  | } /** End of 'Initialize_Tcl' **/
444  | 
445  | /*++++
446  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
447  |  ** 									     **
448  |  **   Function:		InitializeModuleCommands			     **
449  |  ** 									     **
450  |  **   Description:	Initialization of the passed Tcl interpreter. At     **
451  |  **			first the standard Tcl and (if required) TclX initi- **
452  |  **			alization is called. Thereafter all module commands  **
453  |  **			callback function are defined.			     **
454  |  ** 									     **
455  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
456  |  ** 									     **
457  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp	 *interp	The Tcl Interpreter  **
458  |  **							to be initilized     **
459  |  ** 									     **
460  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_OK		All done, Success	     **
461  |  **				TCL_ERROR	Failure anywhere	     **
462  |  ** 									     **
463  |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
464  |  ** 									     **
465  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
466  |  ++++*/
467  | 
468  | int InitializeModuleCommands( Tcl_Interp* interp)
469  | {
470  | 
471  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
472  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_InitializeModuleCommands, NULL);
473  | #endif
474  | 
475  |     /**
476  |      **  General initialization of the Tcl interpreter
477  |      **/
478  |     if( Tcl_Init( interp) == TCL_ERROR)
479  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_INIT_TCL, LOC, NULL))
480  | 	    goto unwind0;
481  | 
482  | #ifdef  HAS_TCLXLIBS
483  | 
484  |     /**
485  |      **  Extended Tcl initialization if configured so ...
486  |      **/
487  | 
488  | #if (TCL_MAJOR_VERSION > 8 || TCL_MAJOR_VERSION == 8 && TCL_MINOR_VERSION > 3)
489  |     if( Tclx_Init( interp) == TCL_ERROR)
490  | #elif (TCL_MAJOR_VERSION > 7 || TCL_MAJOR_VERSION == 7 && TCL_MINOR_VERSION > 5)
491  |     if( Tclxcmd_Init( interp) == TCL_ERROR)
492  | #else
493  |     if( TclXCmd_Init( interp) == TCL_ERROR)
494  | #endif
495  |     {
496  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_INIT_TCLX, LOC, NULL))
497  | 	    goto unwind0;
498  |     }
499  | 
500  | #endif  /* HAS_TCLXLIBS */
501  | 
502  | #ifdef	AUTOLOADPATH
503  | 
504  |     /**
505  |      ** Extend autoload path
506  |      **/
507  |     if( TCL_OK != Tcl_Eval( interp,
508  | 	"if [info exists auto_path] { "
509  | 		"set auto_path [linsert $auto_path 0 " AUTOLOADPATH
510  | 	"]} else {"
511  | 		"set auto_path \"" AUTOLOADPATH "\" }"))
512  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_INIT_ALPATH, LOC, NULL))
513  | 	    goto unwind0;
514  | 
515  | #endif	/* AUTOLOADPATH */
516  | 
517  |     /**
518  |      **   Now for each module command a callback routine has to be specified
519  |      **/
520  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "exit", Module_Tcl_ExitCmd,
521  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
522  | 
523  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "setenv", cmdSetEnv, 
524  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
525  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "unsetenv", cmdUnsetEnv, 
526  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
527  |   
528  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "prepend-path", cmdSetPath, 
529  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
530  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "append-path", cmdSetPath, 
531  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
532  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "remove-path", cmdRemovePath, 
533  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
534  | 
535  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "module-info", cmdModuleInfo, 
536  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
537  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "module", cmdModule, 
538  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
539  | 
540  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "module-whatis", cmdModuleWhatis, 
541  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
542  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "module-verbosity", cmdModuleVerbose, 
543  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
544  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "module-user", cmdModuleUser, 
545  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
546  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "module-log", cmdModuleLog, 
547  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
548  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "module-trace", cmdModuleTrace, 
549  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
550  | 
551  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "module-alias", cmdModuleAlias, 
552  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
553  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "module-version", cmdModuleVersion, 
554  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
555  |   
556  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "set-alias", cmdSetAlias, 
557  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
558  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "unset-alias", cmdSetAlias, 
559  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
560  | 
561  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "conflict", cmdConflict, 
562  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
563  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "prereq", cmdPrereq, 
564  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
565  | 
566  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "is-loaded", cmdIsLoaded, 
567  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
568  | 
569  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "chdir", cmdChDir,
570  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
571  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "system", cmdSystem, 
572  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
573  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "uname", cmdUname, 
574  | 		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
575  | 
576  |     Tcl_CreateCommand( interp, "x-resource", cmdXResource,
577  |  		       (ClientData) shell_derelict,(void (*)(ClientData)) NULL);
578  | 
579  |     return( TCL_OK);			/** -------- EXIT (SUCCESS) -------> **/
580  | 
581  | unwind0:
582  |     return( TCL_ERROR);			/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
583  | 
584  | } /** End of 'InitializeModuleCommands' **/
585  | 
586  | /*++++
587  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
588  |  ** 									     **
589  |  **   Function:		Setup_Environment				     **
590  |  ** 									     **
591  |  **   Description:Define all variables to be found in the current	     **
592  |  **			shell environment as Tcl variables in the passed     **
593  |  **			Tcl interpreter.				     **
594  |  **			Assign as value 0 to all of them. ??? Why ???	     **
595  |  ** 									     **
596  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
597  |  ** 									     **
598  |  **   Parameters:	Tcl_Interp	 *interp	Attched Tcl interpr. **
599  |  ** 									     **
600  |  **   Result:		int	TCL_ERROR	Variable could not be set up **
601  |  **				0		Success ??? TCL_OK ???	     **
602  |  ** 									     **
603  |  **   Attached Globals:	environ						     **
604  |  ** 									     **
605  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
606  |  ++++*/
607  | 
608  | int Setup_Environment( Tcl_Interp*	interp)
609  | {
610  | 
611  |     int   	 i, 			/** loop counter		     **/
612  | 		 envsize = 0;		/** Total size of the environment    **/
613  |     char	*eq;			/** Temp. val. used for location the **/
614  | 					/** Equal sign.			     **/
615  |     char	*loaded;		/** The currently loaded modules     **/
616  |  
617  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
618  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_Setup_Environment, NULL);
619  | #endif
620  | 
621  |     /** 
622  |      **  Scan the whole environment value by value.
623  |      **  Count its size
624  |      **/
625  |     for( i = 0; environ[i]; i++) {
626  | 
627  | 	envsize += strlen( environ[i]) + 1;
628  | 
629  | 	/**
630  | 	 **  Locate the equal sign and terminate the string at its position.
631  | 	 **/
632  | 	eq = environ[i];
633  | 	while( *eq++ != '=' && *eq);
634  | 	*(eq - 1) = '\0';
635  | 
636  | 	/**
637  | 	 **  Now set up a Tcl variable of the same name and value as the
638  | 	 **  environment variable
639  | 	 **/
640  | 	if( Tcl_SetVar( interp, environ[i], eq, 0) == (char *) NULL)
641  | 	    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_SET_VAR, LOC, environ[i], NULL))
642  | 		goto unwind0;
643  | 
644  | 	/**
645  | 	 **  Reinstall the changed environment
646  | 	 **/
647  | 	*(eq - 1) = '=';
648  | 
649  |     } /** for **/
650  | 
651  |     /**
652  |      ** Reconstruct the _LMFILES_ environment variable
653  |      **/
654  |     loaded = getLMFILES( interp);
655  |     if( loaded)
656  | 	if( Tcl_SetVar2( interp, "env", "_LMFILES_", loaded,
657  | 			 TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY) == (char *) NULL)
658  | 	    if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_SET_VAR, LOC, environ[i], NULL))
659  | 		goto unwind0;
660  | 
661  |     return( TCL_OK);			/** -------- EXIT (SUCCESS) -------> **/
662  | 
663  | unwind0:
664  |     return( TCL_ERROR);			/** -------- EXIT (FAILURE) -------> **/
665  | 
666  | } /** end of 'Setup_Environment' **/
667  | 
668  | /*++++
669  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
670  |  ** 									     **
671  |  **   Function:		TieStdout, UnTieStdout				     **
672  |  ** 									     **
673  |  **   Description:	TieStdout closes the 'stdout' handle and reopens it  **
674  |  **			as 'stderr'. The original 'stdout' handle is passed  **
675  |  **			back to the caller.				     **
676  |  **			UnTieStdout reverts this by reopening 'stdout' as the**
677  |  **			handle passed as parameter			     **
678  |  ** 									     **
679  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
680  |  ** 									     **
681  |  **   Parameters:	int	saved_stdout	Handle to be used for rein-  **
682  |  **						stalling stdout		     **
683  |  ** 									     **
684  |  **   Result:		int	The (just reinstalled or saved) stdout handle**
685  |  ** 									     **
686  |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
687  |  ** 									     **
688  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
689  |  ++++*/
690  | 
691  | int TieStdout( void) {
692  |     int save;
693  | 
694  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
695  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_TieStdout, NULL);
696  | #endif
697  | 
698  |     if( 0 > (save = dup(1)))
699  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_DUP, LOC, _fil_stdout, NULL))
700  | 	    goto unwind0;
701  | 
702  |     if( 0 > close( 1))
703  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_CLOSE, LOC, _fil_stdout, NULL))
704  | 	    goto unwind0;
705  | 
706  |     /**
707  |      ** dup used the very first closed handle for duplication. Since stdout
708  |      ** has just been closed, this will be reopened as stderr here.
709  |      **/
710  |     if( 0 > (dup(2)))
711  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_DUP, LOC, _fil_stderr, NULL))
712  | 	    goto unwind0;
713  | 
714  |     return( save);			/** ------- EXIT (RESULT)  --------> **/
715  | 
716  | unwind0:
717  |     return( -1);			/** ------- EXIT (FAILURE) --------> **/
718  | }
719  | 
720  | int UnTieStdout( int saved_stdout) {
721  | 
722  |     int		retval;
723  | 
724  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_2
725  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_UnTieStdout, NULL);
726  | #endif
727  | 
728  |     if( 0 > close( 1))
729  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_CLOSE, LOC, _fil_stdout, NULL))
730  | 	    goto unwind0;
731  | 
732  |     if( 0 > (retval = dup( saved_stdout)))
733  | 	if( OK != ErrorLogger( ERR_DUP, LOC, _fil_stdout, NULL))
734  | 	    goto unwind0;
735  | 
736  |     return( retval);
737  | 
738  | unwind0:
739  |     return( -1);			/** ------- EXIT (FAILURE) --------> **/
740  | }
741  | 
742  | /*++++
743  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
744  |  ** 									     **
745  |  **   Function:		SetStartupFiles					     **
746  |  ** 									     **
747  |  **   Description:	Collects all startupfiles used by the various shells **
748  |  **			in the array 'shell_startups'. This function does not**
749  |  **			care if the startup file do not exist!		     **
750  |  ** 									     **
751  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
752  |  ** 									     **
753  |  **   Parameters:	shell_name	the shell being used		     **
754  |  **   Result:		shell_startups	NULL terminated list of startup files**
755  |  **					for the shell			     **
756  |  **					returns NULL if an error	     **
757  |  **   Attached Globals:	-						     **
758  |  ** 									     **
759  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
760  |  ++++*/
761  | 
762  | char **SetStartupFiles(char *shell_name)
763  | {
764  | 
765  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL
766  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_SetStartupFiles, NULL);
767  | #endif
768  | 
769  |     /**
770  |      ** CSH
771  |      **/
772  |     if( (strcmp( "csh", shell_name) == 0)) {
773  | 
774  |        return cshStartUps;
775  | 
776  |     /**
777  |      ** TCSH
778  |      **/
779  |     } else if((strcmp("tcsh", shell_name) == 0)) {
780  | 
781  |        return tcshStartUps;
782  | 
783  |     /**
784  |      ** SH and KSH
785  |      ** ??? What's about .environ ???
786  |      **/
787  |     } else if((strcmp("sh", shell_name) == 0) ||
788  | 	      (strcmp("ksh", shell_name) == 0)) {
789  | 
790  |        return shStartUps;
791  | 
792  |     /**
793  |      ** BASH
794  |      ** ??? doesn't this guy use the SH startups, too ???
795  |      **/
796  |     } else if((strcmp("bash", shell_name) == 0)) { 
797  | 
798  |        return bashStartUps;
799  | 
800  |     /**
801  |      ** ZSH
802  |      **/
803  |     } else if((strcmp("zsh", shell_name) == 0)) { 
804  | 
805  |        return zshStartUps;
806  |        
807  |     /**
808  |      **  All of the remainig "shells" are not supposed to used startup
809  |      **  files
810  |      **/
811  |     } else {
812  | 
813  |        return genericStartUps;
814  |     }
815  | 
816  | } /** End of 'SetStartupFiles' **/
817  | 
818  | /*++++
819  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
820  |  ** 									     **
821  |  **   Function:		set_shell_properties				     **
822  |  ** 									     **
823  |  **   Description:	Normalize the current calling shell to one of the    **
824  |  **			basic shells defining the variable and alias syntax  **
825  |  ** 									     **
826  |  **   First Edition:	1991/10/23					     **
827  |  ** 									     **
828  |  **   Parameters:	const char	*name	Invoking shell name	     **
829  |  ** 									     **
830  |  **   Result:		char*			Shell derelict name	     **
831  |  ** 									     **
832  |  **   Attached Globals:	shell_derelict					     **
833  |  ** 			shell_cmd_separator				     **
834  |  ** 									     **
835  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
836  |  ++++*/
837  | 
838  | static char	*set_shell_properties(	const char	*name) 
839  | {
840  | 
841  | #if WITH_DEBUGGING_UTIL_3
842  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_set_shell_properties, NULL);
843  | #endif
844  | 
845  |     /**
846  |      ** Loop through the shell properties matrix until a match is found
847  |      **/
848  |     int i = 0;
849  | 
850  |     while (shellprops[i][0]) {
851  | 	if( !strcmp(name,shellprops[i][0])) {	/* found match */
852  | 	    shell_name		= shellprops[i][0];
853  | 	    shell_derelict	= shellprops[i][1];
854  | 	    shell_init		= shellprops[i][2];
855  | 	    shell_cmd_separator	= shellprops[i][3];
856  | 	    return ((char *) name);
857  | 	}
858  | 	i++;
859  |     }
860  | 
861  |     shell_name		= NULL;
862  |     shell_derelict	= NULL;
863  |     shell_init		= NULL;
864  |     shell_cmd_separator	= NULL;
865  |     /**
866  |      **  Oops! Undefined shell name ...
867  |      **/
868  |     return( NULL);
869  | 
870  | } /** End of 'set_shell_properties' **/
